Award.AwardTitle: Nonlinear Sobolev Inequalities, Potential Theory and Harmonic Analysis
Award.AbstractNarration:
This mathematics research project develops methods of potential theory and harmonic analysis that are applicable to the study of geometric integral inequalities, existence and regularity problems, and estimates of solutions for important classes of fully nonlinear and quasilinear equations and inequalities with singular coefficients and singular data. Significant extensions of Hessian Sobolev and Poincare inequalities of Trudinger and Wang, estimates of solutions in terms of Wolff's potentials, as well as sharp estimates of kernels of Neumann series will be obtained for integral operators, Green's functions and the conditional gauge associated with fractional Schrodinger operators. Among the tools employed will be dyadic models, maximal and singular integral operators on non-homogeneous spaces, non-standard duality, and weighted norm inequalities with indefinite weights, along with diverse techniques from the theory of partial differential equations.


This mathematics research project will bring a deeper understanding of fundamental nonlinear and fractal phenomena for complex systems governed by nonlinear laws and nonlocal forces arising in applied sciences and engineering, with potential applications to mathematical modeling of non-Newtonian fluids, heat transfer, elasticity, control theory. The techniques to be employed will bridge several areas of mathematics, such as differential geometry, mathematical physics and conformal geometry. The resulting synergies will enrich the arsenal of analytical tools and available techniques, and will attract more students and young researchers to this dynamic area of mathematics and its applications.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This research on the interface between several active branches of mathematics, including harmonic analysis, nonlinear potential theory and differential equations, resulted in solution of several challenging problems of current interest in analysis, differential and conformal geometry, and mathematical physics. We have broadened the area of applications of nonlinear analysis, enriched the arsenal of tools and techniques available, and attracted a number of graduate students, postdoctoral fellows and young researchers to this dynamic area of mathematics and its applications. Our studies resulted in deeper understanding of nonlinear phenomena arising in theoretical physics, mechanics of materials, engineering and applied sciences. This includes fundamental problems which appear in fluid dynamics, elasticity, control theory, heat transfer, quantum mechanics, etc. 

We obtained sharp estimates of solutions to important classes of linear and nonlinear differential and integral equations; studied their singularities, as well as existence, uniqueness and regularity questions useful in applications; gave two-sided estimates of Green's functions; introduced a new potential adapted specifically for a broad class of nonlinear problems; established necessary and sufficient conditions for weighted norm inequalities and Fourier multipliers, and studied the corresponding spectral properties. 

This research has been used in teaching of graduate courses, and presented in  seminars, international and national research conferences and workshops which contributed to training of graduate students and young researchers. It serves as a basis of several ongoing Ph.D. projects, and has resulted in a Ph.D. dissertation, and in a number of publications joint with PI's current and former Ph.D. students in leading international mathematics journals.
